14th Street east from but not including Sixth Avenue, from about 56 and 57 West 14th Street.  The curch at the left, of which only a glimpse is visible, is the Scotch Presbyterian Church.  About 1892.

Additional note, in the right hand portion of the frame you can see the original R.H. Macy & Co. building before it moved in 1902 to 34th & Broadway.

711286f-b.text:
(1) Civic Repertory Theatre, formerly the 14th Street Theatre, 14th Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Sixth Avenue.
April 6, 1928
P.L. Sperr.

(2) The same, another view.
June 16, 1928.
P.L. Sperr

(3 & 4)
A more inclusive view eastward to Sixth Ave. and showing the elevated line thereon. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.

According to the New York Times of April 1, 1938 the theatre shown will be demolished and replaced with a modern motion picture house. This structure opened in 1866 as the Theatre Francais, was rebuilt in 1871 and name the Lyceum, later to become the 14th Street Theatre.  For a fuller account see either the above newspaper or Kings Handbook of New York published in 1892.

711285f-a.text:
14th Street, at the N.W. corner of Sixth Avenue ("E1" thereon and which will shortly be razed). The vacant plot at the left was the site of the former Civic Repertory Theatre and upon which will rise a modern neighborhood motion-picture house.

This building was opened in 1866 as the Theatre Francaise, and during the first year Jacob Grau presented Histori there in her American premeiere. The home was rebuilt in 1871 and renamed the Lyceum. As time passed, the type of productions changed, tho at one time it was a center of the social and dramatic life.

It became the 14th Street Theatre later and since 1926, the Civic Repertory Theatre. The New York Times of April 1, 1938 carried an article to the above effect.

June 16, 1938.

P.L. Sperr

(1)
Sixth Avenue, west side, north from but not including 14th Street.
April 26, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a point slightly northward. In the background (from left to right) can be seen the towers of the old Seigel Cooper Department Store
and the Empire State Building.
October 27, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
